messages.subject: Re: [nihonto] Question on Tsuba Theme / Akasaka
messages.msgSnippet: Steve, Thanks. I m afraid it is one that is going up to pay for the bills and taxes (touchee IRS!, -love to hate you). Funny thing- I had not noticed the bird
messages.messageBody:
Steve,

Thanks.
I'm afraid it is one that is going up to pay for
the bills and taxes (touchee IRS!, -love to hate you).

Funny thing- I had not noticed the bird worked into
the design until tonight. Looking at it closely, there
are little feathers notched on its wings. I had just
assumed it was a part of the pine trees element of the
design.

Curran


--- W steve <steven_88_2000@...> wrote:

> Hi Curran,
>
> Yes, I believe it is a reference to Matsushima. The
> mountainous scape, together with the rough surf,
> and,
> of course, the pines (plural) collectively suggest
> Matsushima. Part of the draw of this place, as I
> understand it, is the contrast of the silent,
> twisted
> pines with the roiling drama of the waters buffeting
> these isles... This tsuba captures this quite
> beautifully, I think... Great tsuba, Curran...
>
> Steve
>
>
> --- Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
>
> > Steve, Barry, & Milt,
> >
> > Thanks. I believe that is exactly it.
> > Now the follow up question.-
> > Is this Akasaka tsuba a theme reference to
> > Matsushima,
> > reference to something else, or just an Autumn
> > theme?
> >
> > http://tinyurl.com/32vfje
> >
> > Best,
> >
> > Curran
> >
> >
> >
> >
> > --- W steve <steven_88_2000@...> wrote:
> >
> > > Hi Curran,
> > >
> > > I believe this would be Matsushima, a group of
> > > islands
> > > off the NE coast (I think) of Honshu, made
> famous
> > in
> > > a
> > > haiku by Matsuo Basho in the 17th century... I
> > > think
> > > the significance is simply that the viewing of
> > these
> > > pine-strewn isles is highly evocative, and
> > captures
> > > the essence of the Japanese spirit somehow...
> > >
> > > Steve
> > >
> > > --- Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > > List,
> > > >
> > > > A while back the theme of:
> > > >
> > > > "Small pine trees on small rock islands,
> > > > surrounded by wind and waves"
> > > >
> > > > was discussed on one of the lists as a
> reference
> > > to
> > > > a
> > > > particular place, and I believe to a poem. Can
> > > > anyone
> > > > refresh my memory as to the location and
> > relevance
> > > > of
> > > > this place (& theme)?
> > > >
> > > > Curran
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > > >
> > >
> >
>
